Text: Endow the king with Your justice, O God, the royal son with Your righteousness.
Context: Psalm 72 is a royal psalm traditionally attributed to Solomon. It is a prayer for the king's righteous rule and may have been used in coronation ceremonies.

Text: May he judge Your people with righteousness and Your afflicted with justice.
Context: The psalmist continues the prayer for the king to judge rightly, emphasizing justice for the people, especially the afflicted.

Text: May the mountains bring prosperity to the people, and the hills, righteousness.
Context: This verse conveys a symbolic wish that the reign of the king brings stability and prosperity, represented by the mountains and hills.

Text: May he vindicate the afflicted among the people, save the children of the needy, and crush the oppressor.
Context: The verse reflects a deep longing for the king to protect the most vulnerable in society and to deal justly with oppressors.

Text: May he endure as long as the sun, as long as the moon, through all generations.
Context: The psalmist prays for the king's enduring rule, comparing his longevity to the celestial bodies which are timeless.

Text: May he be like rain falling on a mown field, like showers watering the earth.
Context: In this metaphor, the king's influence is likened to rain that nurtures growth, suggesting a reign that fosters the flourishing of life.

Text: In his days may the righteous flourish and prosperity abound, till the moon is no more.
Context: The psalm expresses a hope for a golden age of righteousness and abundance during the king's reign.

Text: May he rule from sea to sea, and from the River to the ends of the earth.
Context: This verse speaks to the ideal of a vast kingdom, suggesting a desire for the king's dominion and influence to expand greatly.

Text: May the nomads bow before him, and his enemies lick the dust.
Context: This is a depiction of submission to the king by nomadic peoples and enemies, indicating a position of power and respect.

Text: May the kings of Tarshish and distant shores bring tribute; may the kings of Sheba and Seba present him gifts.
Context: The psalmist envisions foreign dignitaries acknowledging the king's greatness through tribute, signifying international respect and alliance.

Text: May all kings bow down to him and all nations serve him.
Context: This continues the theme of a universal recognition and subjugation to the king's rule, reflecting a high aspiration for the king's authority.

Text: For he will deliver the needy who cry out, the afflicted with no one to help.
Context: The king is portrayed as a protector of the defenseless, highlighting his role as a savior to the destitute and helpless.

Text: He will take pity on the weak and needy and save the needy from death.
Context: This verse emphasizes the king's compassion and his role in providing deliverance from death for the poor and vulnerable.

Text: He will rescue their souls from oppression and violence, for precious is their blood in his sight.
Context: The king is presented as a staunch defender against abuse and violence, valuing the lives of his subjects highly.

Text: Long may he live! May gold from Sheba be given to him. May people ever pray for him and bless him all day long.
Context: This is a benediction seeking a long life for the king, prosperity through tribute, and continual prayers and blessings from the people.

Text: May grain abound throughout the land; on the tops of the hills may it sway. May the crops flourish like Lebanon and thrive like the grass of the field.
Context: The psalmist prays for agricultural abundance as a sign of a blessed and prosperous reign.

Text: May his name endure forever; may it continue as long as the sun. All nations will be blessed through him, and they will call him blessed.
Context: A desire for the king's enduring legacy and reputation, with a global acknowledgment of his positive influence.

Text: Praise be to the Lord God, the God of Israel, who alone does marvelous deeds.
Context: This is a doxology attributing all wonders and praise to God, acknowledging his singular role in the unfolding of marvelous events.

Text: Blessed be His glorious name forever; may the whole earth be filled with His glory. Amen and Amen.
Context: A form of praise exalting God's name and expressing a wish for his glory to fill the earth, concluding with an emphatic agreement.

Text: This concludes the prayers of David son of Jesse.
Context: The final verse acts as an editorial note, likely added later, attributing the preceding prayers to David and marking the end of his contributions.
